At this point, it's** my experience** VS the **meta experience**.
Although i've used the term _**meta sheep**_ in quite a few of my arguments, it's only reserved for people who follow the meta blindly and don't think about why the certain meta exists, in order to find a way to break away from the mold successfully.

Meta isn't something that's inherently bad. It's a way of playing the game, according to the collective community experience. Which means that certain roles/champions are considered to have greater chances of victory at that time, therefore seeing more play.
Naturally, champions that meta champions somewhat counter are out of it, for a time.
Following the meta isn't something that should be considered as bad. It's a great way of experiencing the game and learning how any why something works, at any given time. But it becomes bad when players simply play according to it, completely refusing to believe that other champions (that are out of the meta) even exist or won't accept them as legit picks, when they finally are about to be played.

Darius bot is definitely out of the meta. But it may work. Mainly because he's just a champion that can take a lot of abuse and has sustain + absurd damage when he gets a fight right. However, you can't blame your team for not trusting you with that pick.
Even if you're a Master player, you're playing with other Master players. They don't have, or are required, to trust you with such an unusual pick but one thing is for certain: they do not have the right to take away the role you were assigned to, if this is your choice for a champion.

Which means if they disagree with this decision, they can either play it out and report you if you're trolling them for a specific reason or queue dodge. On the flip side, if they are taking your role because they don't want to let you, you have a valid reason to report them, if you didn't agree to this switch.

Your opinion matters no more or less than anybody else's.
You rank is a badge, but it is a badge that comes with absolutely 0 authority.
That badge also isn't a demotion, and it shouldn't be some kind of scarlet letter either.

Thats being said, I appreciate that in the multitude of debates / arguments / discussions i have had with you in my times on the boards, you never pulled rank as an excuse / disqualifier (at least not that I remember) and that is a +1 in my book.

That's honestly one of the bigger reasons why I stopped playing. I managed to get into Plat 5 but I started thinking to myself, "Gee, I assume the higher up I go, the more meta everything will be because everyone up here are so HELLBENT on winning via the strongest (read: OP for patch) teamcomps". 

Seriously though, congrats on Masters. Few people can ever say that they got that high in the entire world.

>the more meta everything will be because everyone up here are so HELLBENT on winning via the strongest

The beauty about high elo is that even though they stick to meta, you can pick a champ you are really good at (keywords: REALLY GOOD) and destroy the meta. You can do this in any elo obviously but the higher you go, the better your mechanics and game knowledge and the easier to carry with the non-meta champ.

With any competitive environment there will always be the safest and most reliable choices, because the rules to the game always are the same. Because you are at a high enough level where almost all the players are at the top skill and decision making wise, the only variance besides specific in game mess ups is champion selection, so players obviously will contest and selectively pick champions with the highest chance of an advantage. 

The main way to rise above meta dominance is to simply be marginally better than your opponent despite champion picks. This is why pro players are able to stream non meta picks in challenger, because they train much harder and have much better decision making than challenger players, which out weighs the small champion balance advantages of the other team's meta picks.

Games are decided so early because at the highest level of play players don't make plays, they punish them and lock in that advantage. Early game is too decisive because once there is an advantage, it takes a mess up from the winning team to be able to come back, which rarely happens in top ELO. This paired with safety of meta picks and already present snowball supplying mechanics (objective control, wave push changes, vision dominance) makes the early game the breeding ground of the winner, and why jungle has been a touchy subject especially this season.

I wish I could suggest a gamefixing change that would solve all this, but higher ELO has been like this for a while if you pay attention to analysts like LS and being someone in Platinum doesn't give me any credentials to know what it really is like playing at challenger level (aside from stray challenger players appearing in my normals). 

Personally I think a lot of the issues are rooted in vision right now. You can argue champion balance all you want, but it will always be screwy because of how many variables are at play. Vision, however, is a simple mechanic available to everyone that can be capitalized in so many ways (preventing ganks, securing plays, gathering gold information, determining enemy jungle paths, etc). I'd like to see vision become more dynamic while maintaining all of its functions, so that you can utilize it more to press meaningful advantages instead of just getting dominated in a lane because of rules you can't control. Right now vision is a cushion, not a pathway.

**Hope this sheds some light for anyone not too informed about high ELO and is a bit shut in for opinions because of how boards don't really represent higher play.**
